thread.title: 'The Martian' blasts to top of box office
thread.title_full: 'The Martian' blasts to top of box office

title: 'The Martian' blasts to top of box office
text:
Matt Damon in a scene from the film, "The Martian." (Photo: Aidan Monaghan)
CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Matt Damon and The Martian shot into a whole different galaxy at the box office, rocket propelling to a $55 million opening weekend, according to studio estimates.
The Ridley Scott-directed film about an astronaut stranded on Mars came close to matching the record opening for October, nearly catching Sandra Bullock's role as a solo astronaut in peril in Gravity which took in $55.8 weekend in its October 2013 opening weekend.
The brainy, science-filled Martian script, which Scott says was too close to reality to call science fiction, was a hit with critics and audience members alike — scoring a 94% critical approval rating on RottenTomatoes.com and an A grade on the audience-rated Cinemascore.
Distributor Twentieth Century Fox also received a major marketing bonus with ground-breaking science news last week that NASA had discovered evidence of recent flowing water on Mars.
FLORIDA TODAY
NASA finds evidence of recent flowing water on Mars
"That's a studio executive's dream to have that kind of positive news associated with your movie, the perfect coincidence," says Paul Dergarabedian, box office analyst for Rentrak. "The math and science crowd has it going on right now at the movies, science is positively cool. The Martian is not a sequel, but it still had this massive opening."
USA TODAY
Major stars being left for dead in theaters
Adam Sandler's animated Dracula in Hotel Transylvania continued to score in the family entertainment front with a second place finish of $33 million, one week after taking the box office crown. The monster-filled Sony film has an impressive total of $90.5 million in its second weekend.
Dracula, voiced by Adam Sandler and Vlad, voiced by Mel Brooks, appear in a scene from "Hotel Transylvania 2." (Photo: Sony Pictures Animation)
Emily Blunt, Benicio Del Toro and Josh Brolin's look at the brutal of world of drug trafficking in Sicario continued to expand in theaters across the country, taking third place with $12 million. The box office total for the film directed by Denis Villeneuve is $15 million
Robert De Niro and Anne Hathaway's role in Nancy Meyers' The Intern took fourth place in its second weekend earning $11.6 million for a box office total of $36.5 million.
Maze Runner: The Scorch Trials rounded out the top five with $7.7 million, with a total of $63.2 million after 17 days in theaters.
The October weekend in the beginning of awards season was filled with quality offerings, with three nationwide releases heralded as must-sees by critics on RottenTomatoes.com for the first time in 2015 — The Martian (94% critical approval), Sicario (93%) and The Walk (86%).
The Walk , featuring Joseph Gordon Levitt's role depicting the 1974 high-wire walk between the World Trade Center towers, saw its IMAX debut in 448 locations, taking in a solid $1.6 million in its limited release. The Walk expands to 2,500 theaters next weekend.
Final numbers are due Monday.
Joseph Gordon-Levitt portrays Philippe Petite in a scene from, "The Walk." (Photo: Sony Pictures)
